Note 001 Propositional Logic and Quantifiers (12 mins read)

Proposition are functions that takes in some input and output True or False:

For example, we can define the proposition “x is greater than 5” as . If we replace x with 4, it will make the statement becomes “4 is greater than 5”, a wrong statement. If we replace x with 6, it will make the statement becomes “6 is greater than 5”, a true statement. Wow, it’s just like a function in python :

Similarly, “x is less than 6” can be written as such that:

Further compounding proposition with logic will also give functions, for example:

Here’s today’s exercise: Prove the above expression is correct. Hint: use Truth Table (because this is the only way you learnt so far to prove things)

What exactly is Universal Quantifier and :

The is a sequence of “and” and is a sequence of “or”. Although this is in your note, I cannot stress it more. For example, we can denote the proposition “x is non-negative” as P(x). And what’s the statement “All natural number are non-negative” in propositional logic? It is

, which is equivalently as

Similarly, the statement “for any real number x, there is natural number greater than x” can be written as , which can be expanded as This is one of the most important theorem in anlysis, which is probably be the first thing you learn if you take Math 104. Notice I expaned using the “or” operator “”, but I cannot expand , this is simply because I cannot iterate through all the real number. Formally, real numbers are “uncountable” and we will learn about this later.
